name: Learning Clotho
description: Learn how Clotho can simplify and automate your genetic engineering workflows.

about.help: Welcome to the Clotho Intro Trail. Get started to learn the Basics of DNA and how to use Clotho to automate your synthetic biology workflow.

contents.description: Introduce concepts of DNA and basic sequence manipulation, and learn how to use Clotho to automate those manipulations

contents.params:
Clotho is a software environment for authoring and sharing the tools and data needed to perform a synthetic biology project. This tutorial will guide you through the basics of genetic design and Clotho usage.

Videos like this will help you get up to speed. This one will give you a brief introduction to DNA and Synthetic Biology. Feel free to skip ahead if this isn't new to you.

pages.title: Reverse Complement
pages.help: Boxes like the one below are quizzes. This Trail will ask you to answer questions about DNA manipulation. Watch the videos on each page if you need to brush up on your knowledge (click OK and peek behind this window), but make sure you understand each quiz before moving forward.

pages.title: The Command Bar
pages.help:
The Command Bar provides a simple interface for running functions in clotho.

Type f to focus the Command Bar input. Autocompletions are presented as you type.

Type a to show the Activity Log, which shows your recent interaction with Clotho.

contents.params:
Answer the quiz by running your own function!

In the Command Bar, type revcomp and select the reverse complement function, then copy-paste the sequence in the quiz. Grab the resulting value from the Activity Log and paste it in the quiz.

contents.description: Move beyond simple sequence manipulation to DNA-enzyme and DNA-DNA interactions, and predicting them in Clotho

contents.params: Select an Enzyme from the tool below to see where it will cut the sequence. Cut marks are denoted by arrows, and the recognition site is colored in.

The tool below includes a few sets of primers and backbones. You can see the alignment of the primers, and the DNA fragment that results after PCR. Notice that some will copy the inner fragment (normal PCR), and others the outer fragment (EIPCR), depending on the orientation of the primers.

Try editing the primers or sequence yourself!

contents.description: Construction files list a sequence of reactions to yield a final product, which can be predicted in Clotho

pages.title: Examining
pages.help: A simple workflow involves the amplification of your gene of interest via PCR, and digesting it to give it specific sticky ends on each side. A plasmid backbone is cut with restriction enzymes to yield ends complimentary to those of the fragment containing your gene of interest, and a ligation adds your fragment to the backbone. Your final product could then be transformed into bacteria, which would synthesize your gene of interest.
